FastSurvivalSVM 0.0.1
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • FastSurvivalSVM: Kernel Survival SVM Models in R
    • Using Custom Kernels with FastSurvivalSVM: The Wavelet Kernel

    Bagging of FastKernelSurvivalSVM with covariate sub-sampling

    fastsvm_bagging_fit.Rd

    Fit a bagging ensemble of sksurv.svm.FastKernelSurvivalSVM models, using fast_kernel_surv_svm_fit() as the base learner.

    fastsvm_bagging_fit(
  data,
  time_col = "t",
  delta_col = "delta",
  n_estimators = 50L,
  mtry = NULL,
  sample_frac = 1,
  replace = TRUE,
  kernels = "rbf",
  kernel_prob = NULL,
  alpha = 1,
  rank_ratio = 0,
  fit_intercept = FALSE,
  parallel = FALSE,
  seed = NULL,
  ...
)

    Arguments

    data

    A data.frame containing survival time, event indicator, and covariates.

    time_col

    Name of the column in data containing survival times.

    delta_col

    Name of the column in data containing the event indicator (1 = event, 0 = right censoring).

    n_estimators

    Integer; number of base learners (bootstrap replicates) in the ensemble.

    mtry

    Integer; number of covariates to be used in each base learner. If NULL, defaults to floor(sqrt(p)), where p is the number of available covariates.

    sample_frac

    Fraction of rows to sample for each base learner. If replace = TRUE, sample_frac = 1 corresponds to standard bootstrap resampling. If smaller than 1, it performs subsampling.

    replace

    Logical; if TRUE, sample rows with replacement (bootstrap). If FALSE, sample without replacement.

    kernels

    Kernel specification:

    • A single value: either a character string (e.g. "rbf", "poly") or an R function function(x, z) ..., used in all base models.

    • A list() of kernels (each element a string or function); for each base model, one kernel is sampled from this list.

    Kernel functions can be factory functions that already fix their hyperparameters (e.g. make_wavelet_kernel(A = 0.5)).

    kernel_prob

    Optional numeric vector of sampling probabilities for kernels when kernels is a list. Must have the same length as kernels. If NULL, a uniform distribution over kernels is used.

    alpha

    Regularisation parameter for the SVM, passed to FastKernelSurvivalSVM(alpha = ...).

    rank_ratio

    Mixing parameter between ranking and regression objectives (0 <= rank_ratio <= 1), forwarded to the Python estimator. For pure regression on transformed survival times, use rank_ratio = 0.

    fit_intercept

    Logical; if TRUE, include an intercept when there is a regression component (rank_ratio < 1).

    parallel

    Logical; if TRUE, fit base learners in parallel using future.apply. The execution plan must be set by the user using future::plan().

    seed

    Optional integer; seed to be set before bagging. Useful for reproducibility, especially together with future.

    ...

    Additional arguments passed directly to sksurv.svm.FastKernelSurvivalSVM() via fast_kernel_surv_svm_fit(), e.g. gamma, degree, coef0, max_iter, optimizer, tol, etc.

    Value

    An object of class "fastsvm_bagging" with components:

    • models: list of "fastsvm" base learners;

    • subspaces: list of character vectors with the covariate names used in each base learner;

    • time_col, delta_col, x_cols: metadata;

    • rank_ratio: ensemble-level rank_ratio;

    • n_estimators, mtry, sample_frac, replace: ensemble configuration.

    Details

    Each base model is fitted on:

    • a bootstrap (or subsample) of the rows, and

    • a random subset of the covariates (mtry), analogous to Random Forest, but with kernel survival SVMs instead of trees.

    The kernels argument controls how kernels are chosen:

    • If a single value is provided (string or function), the same kernel is used in all base models.

    • If a list() is provided, each element must be a valid kernel (a string or an R function compatible with fast_kernel_surv_svm_fit()), and for each base model one kernel is sampled from this list.

    Machine-learning friendly design:

    • SVM hyperparameters (alpha, rank_ratio, etc.) are explicit, named arguments of this function, suitable for external tuning (e.g., with tidymodels).

    • Hyperparameters of custom kernels should be encoded inside the kernel functions themselves (e.g. make_wavelet_kernel(A = 0.5)). The bagging function does not re-tune kernel hyperparameters at each bootstrap; it only samples among already parameterised kernels.

    This package does not implement new kernel functions itself. The user is expected to:

    • use strings supported by scikit-learn (e.g. "rbf", "poly", "sigmoid", "laplacian", etc.), or

    • pass R functions of the form function(x, z) ... that return a scalar kernel value, as required by FastKernelSurvivalSVM.

    Parallelisation:

    • If parallel = TRUE, base models are fitted in parallel using future.apply (future_lapply), allowing any backend supported by future (multicore, multisession, cluster, etc.).

    • The user must set the execution plan before calling this function, e.g. future::plan(multisession).

    Examples

    if (reticulate::py_module_available("sksurv")) {

  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  ## Example 1: Simple bagging with a fixed RBF kernel (regression mode)
  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  set.seed(123)
  df <- data_generation(n = 300L, prop_cen = 0.10)

  bag_rbf <- fastsvm_bagging_fit(
    data         = df,
    time_col     = "tempo",
    delta_col    = "cens",
    n_estimators = 10L,
    mtry         = 2L,
    kernels      = "rbf",   # scikit-learn RBF kernel
    alpha        = 1,
    rank_ratio   = 0        # pure regression on transformed times
  )

  preds_rbf <- predict(bag_rbf, df)
  head(preds_rbf)

  cindex_rbf <- score_fastsvm_bagging(bag_rbf, df)
  cindex_rbf


  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  ## Example 2: Bagging with a list of kernels (RBF and polynomial)
  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  kernels_list <- list("rbf", "poly")

  bag_mix <- fastsvm_bagging_fit(
    data         = df,
    time_col     = "tempo",
    delta_col    = "cens",
    n_estimators = 15L,
    mtry         = 3L,
    kernels      = kernels_list,
    kernel_prob  = c(0.7, 0.3), # 70% RBF, 30% polynomial
    alpha        = 0.5,
    rank_ratio   = 0
  )

  preds_mix <- predict(bag_mix, df)
  head(preds_mix)

  cindex_mix <- score_fastsvm_bagging(bag_mix, df)
  cindex_mix


  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  ## Example 3: Bagging with custom R kernel functions
  ##             (including hyperparameters)
  ## ------------------------------------------------------------

  # Custom wavelet mother function
  wavelet_mother <- function(u) {
    cos(1.75 * u) * exp(-0.5 * u^2)
  }

  # Multidimensional wavelet kernel with scale parameter A
  wavelet_kernel <- function(x, z, A = 1) {
    x <- as.numeric(x)
    z <- as.numeric(z)
    stopifnot(length(x) == length(z))
    stopifnot(length(A) == 1L, A > 0)

    u <- (x - z) / A
    prod(wavelet_mother(u))
  }

  # Kernel factory fixing the hyperparameter A
  make_wavelet_kernel <- function(A = 1) {
    force(A)
    function(x, z) wavelet_kernel(x, z, A = A)
  }

  # Another example: RBF kernel with tunable sigma
  make_rbf_kernel <- function(sigma = 1) {
    force(sigma)
    function(x, z) {
      x <- as.numeric(x); z <- as.numeric(z)
      d2 <- sum((x - z)^2)
      exp(-d2 / (2 * sigma^2))
    }
  }

  custom_kernels <- list(
    make_wavelet_kernel(A = 0.5),  # wavelet kernel with A = 0.5
    make_rbf_kernel(sigma = 0.8)   # custom RBF kernel with sigma = 0.8
  )

  bag_custom <- fastsvm_bagging_fit(
    data         = df,
    time_col     = "tempo",
    delta_col    = "cens",
    n_estimators = 10L,
    mtry         = 2L,
    kernels      = custom_kernels,  # list of R kernel functions
    alpha        = 1,
    rank_ratio   = 0
  )

  preds_custom <- predict(bag_custom, df)
  head(preds_custom)

  cindex_custom <- score_fastsvm_bagging(bag_custom, df)
  cindex_custom


  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  ## Example 4 (optional): Parallel fitting using future/future.apply
  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  ## Not run by default on CRAN / examples:
  # if (requireNamespace("future.apply", quietly = TRUE)) {
  #   future::plan(future::multisession)
  #   bag_parallel <- fastsvm_bagging_fit(
  #     data         = df,
  #     time_col     = "tempo",
  #     delta_col    = "cens",
  #     n_estimators = 20L,
  #     mtry         = 2L,
  #     kernels      = "rbf",
  #     alpha        = 1,
  #     rank_ratio   = 0,
  #     parallel     = TRUE,
  #     seed         = 999L
  #   )
  #   score_fastsvm_bagging(bag_parallel, df)
  # }


  ## ------------------------------------------------------------
  ## Example 5: Comparing single FastKernelSurvivalSVM (poly)
  ##            vs bagging with randomisation of 3 kernels
  ## ------------------------------------------------------------

  set.seed(456)
  df_poly <- data_generation(n = 300L, prop_cen = 0.10)

  ## (a) Single-model FastKernelSurvivalSVM with polynomial kernel
  fit_poly <- fast_kernel_surv_svm_fit(
    data        = df_poly,
    time_col    = "tempo",
    delta_col   = "cens",
    kernel      = "poly",
    alpha       = 2,
    rank_ratio  = 0,
    degree      = 3L,   # integer required by scikit-learn
    coef0       = 1L
  )

  cindex_poly_single <- score_fastsvm(fit_poly, df_poly)


  ## (b) Bagging with 3 kernels: poly, rbf and wavelet

  # Wavelet mother function
  wavelet_mother2 <- function(u) {
    cos(1.75 * u) * exp(-0.5 * u^2)
  }

  # Wavelet kernel with hyperparameter A
  wavelet_kernel2 <- function(x, z, A = 1) {
    x <- as.numeric(x); z <- as.numeric(z)
    u <- (x - z) / A
    prod(wavelet_mother2(u))
  }

  # Kernel factory: fixes A and returns a function(x, z)
  make_wavelet_kernel2 <- function(A = 1) {
    force(A)
    function(x, z) wavelet_kernel2(x, z, A = A)
  }

  kernels_3 <- list(
    "poly",
    "rbf",
    make_wavelet_kernel2(A = 0.7)
  )

  bag_poly_mix <- fastsvm_bagging_fit(
    data         = df_poly,
    time_col     = "tempo",
    delta_col    = "cens",
    n_estimators = 20L,
    mtry         = 2L,
    kernels      = kernels_3,
    kernel_prob  = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2),  # 40% poly, 40% rbf, 20% wavelet
    alpha        = 2,
    rank_ratio   = 0,
    degree       = 3L,                # used only for poly kernel
    coef0        = 1L
  )

  cindex_poly_bagging <- score_fastsvm_bagging(bag_poly_mix, df_poly)

  ## Compare C-index: single model vs bagging ensemble
  c(
    cindex_poly_single  = cindex_poly_single,
    cindex_poly_bagging = cindex_poly_bagging
  )

}
#>  cindex_poly_single cindex_poly_bagging 
#>           0.6428161           0.8162561
